filedesc.publicationstmt: Charlottesville: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; IATH April 1998
filedesc.updatestmt:
The editors of the William Blake Archive are pleased to announce the publication of seven new electronic editions of Blake's illuminated books. They are: The [First] Book of Urizen Copy G, The Book of Los Copy A, The Book of Ahania Copy A, The Song of Los Copy B, America, a Prophecy Copy A, Europe, a Prophecy Copy E, and Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copy F.
We had announced Urizen Copy G as forthcoming two months ago, but formatting the double-columned text diplomatically in SGML for both Netscape and Internet Explorer proved more taxing and time consuming than anticipated. Such are the joys and tribulations of electronic publishing. Solving the problems there, though, ensured diplomatic transcriptions for Blake's other books with double-columned texts, The Book of Ahania and The Book of Los. Together, these three works are often referred to as Blake's Bible of Hell or, simply, the Urizen books. Urizen, of which there are only seven extant copies, was first produced in 1794, color printed to form Copies A, C, D, E (untraced), F, and J. It was printed again in 1795 to form Copy B, which was produced as part of a set of illuminated books printed on large paper, and then one last time in c. 1818 to form Copy G, which was produced in Blake's late printing and coloring style. The editors are currently working on Copies A, B, C, and F and expect to have them in the Archive by the end of the year. The Book of Ahania and The Book of Los exist in unique copies, with only a few proof impressions extant. They were printed in 1795 and executed in intaglio instead of in relief etching, the technique Blake normally used for his illuminated books. Although their texts are printed in intaglio, their frontispieces are beautifully color printed from the surface of the plates.
With The Song of Los, which consists of two parts entitled "Africa" and "Asia," we complete Blake's other series of illuminated books, sometimes known as the Continental Prophecies, begun in 1793 with America and continued in 1794 with Europe. The copy of The Song of Los included here is one of six extant; all were color printed in the same printing session in 1795.
With fourteen complete copies extant, America is not as rare as these other illuminated books, but Copy A, which was printed and colored in 1795 as part of Blake's large-paper set of books, is, along with Copies K, O, and M, one of only four colored copies—and it was the model for Copy K. Moreover, only it and Copy O have the last four lines on Plate 4, which was masked in the printing of the other copies. The Archive will include Copies M and O (c. 1807 and 1818) later this year.
Only nine copies of Europe are extant, and only two of those, Copies H and O (1795 and 1818), have Plate 3, the Preludium. The Archive will include both of these Copies by the end of the year. Copy E, included here, was lightly color printed on both sides of the paper in 1794 and joins Copy B, color printed more heavily on one side of the paper the same year.
Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copy F is an exquisitely beautiful copy, heavily color printed (especially its frontispiece) in c. 1794, and never before reproduced. It joins Copies C and J (both 1793), and will be joined later this year by Copies G and P (1795 and 1818).
All of these editions have newly edited texts; all images in the editions were scanned from either 4x5 or 8x10 transparencies, nearly all of which were made specifically for the Archive. Like our other editions, these are all SGML-encoded, fully searchable for both text and images and supported by the unique Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates.
The Archive now contains sixteen copies of ten illuminated books. In the coming months, we will be adding copies of All Religions are One, There is No Natural Religion, For the Sexes, Milton, and Jerusalem, along with copies of books already in the Archive but from different printings. Our goal is to have the entire illuminated canon online this year. In addition, work continues on the SGML edition of David V. Erdman's Complete Poetry and Prose of William Blake, which we anticipate releasing sometime this spring.

objinfo.objorder: Bentley Plates 1-3, 9, 5, 12, 6, 14, 7, 8, 22, 10, 11, 16, 13, 15, 17-21, 23, 27, 24-26, 28Bentley Plate 4 was printed for this copy, but not included by Blake. This impression of Bentley Plate 4 is now in the collection of Robert N. Essick. For discussion, see Essick, "Variation, Accident, and Intention in William Blake's *The Book of Urizen*," *Studies in Bibliography* 39 (1986): 230-35.

provenance.name: Library of Congress
provenance.date: Acquired by Rosenwald in 1929; given to the Library of Congress 1945.
provenance.note: Sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 20 Jan. 1852, lot 186 (£8.15s. to Richard Monckton Milnes, First Lord Houghton); Milnes' son, the Earl of Crewe, probably by inheritance in 1885; sold Sotheby's, 30 March 1903, lot 6 (£307 to the dealer Bernard Quaritch, probably acting for William A. White); White by April 1903; sold posthumously from White's collection through A. S. W. Rosenbach to Lessing J. Rosenwald, 1 May 1929, for approximately $5000 (the evaluation given to the work by Rosenbach in records now in the Rosenbach Library, Philadelphia); given by Rosenwald to the Library of Congress, 1945.

desc.objtitle: THE FIRST BOOK of URIZENThe First Book of Urizen, The [First] Book of Urizen, Object 1 (Bentley 1, Erdman 1, Keynes 1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a gloomily lit, rigidly symmetrical composition, leafless, willow-like trees form cave-like arches over the top half of the plate. The words of the title appear between the branches. A fully gowned old man with closed eyes and long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits cross-legged on a large book in the center foreground. Just over his head the lack of color suggests a faint halo. Centered behind him is a pair of stone tablets with arched tops, like tombstones. Lying on the ground to his left and right are two sets of quadrangular stone tablets or, alternatively, the ends of a single long tablet, perhaps a coffin lid. The lighting, trees, and tablets taken together suggest a graveyard setting. Beneath Urizen's feet is an open book. The toes of his right foot emerge from his beard to mark his place in the book. Tree roots sprout to left and right in the foreground beneath the book and tablets. Holding a writing instrument in each hand and resting his arms on the tablets to his left and right, Urizen seems to be copying from the book onto the tablets. The instruments may be a quill (in his right hand) and a graphite pencil or etching needle (in his left hand). Publication information is centered beneath the book.

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits cross-legged on a book. Just over his head the lack of color suggests a faint halo. With both hands, a writing instrument in each, he copies from the book onto stone tablets to his right and left with his arms resting on the tablets. The toes of his right foot mark his place in the book. His eyes are closed or looking sharply downward.

Leafless, willow-like trees with thick trunks on right and left form cave-like arches over the top half of the plate that tightly enclose the tombstone-like tablets behind Urizen. The words of the title appear between the branches, and publication information appears between roots that sprout to left and right at the bottom of the plate.
A large open book on the ground provides a platform for Urizen to sit cross-legged on as he copies its text, which is represented by indecipherable marks.
Urizen writes with an instrument that may be a quill pen in his right hand.
Urizen writes with an instrument that may be a pen, graphite pencil, or etching needle in his left hand.

A stone tablet, or two tablets one on top of the other, provides one of the two surfaces on which Urizen writes. There may be only one tablet with its two ends showing. Its position and material suggest a coffin lid of some sort. Alternatively, the objects on which Urizen's hands rest may be bound books.
A pair of upright tablets resembling tombstones and the tablets of the decalogue sit directly behind Urizen.
The setting altogether suggests a graveyard.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Extensions of the letters of "URIZEN" (line 5) suggest vines, including a loopy spiral introducing the first letter.

component.illusobjdesc: Extensions of the letters of "URIZEN" (line 5) suggest vines, including a loopy spiral introducing the first letter.

desc.objtitle: PRELUDIUM TO THE BOOK OF URIZEN, Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman 2, Keynes 2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Drawn in left profile with her back to the viewer, a young woman wearing a full gown and with her hair pulled back in a bun floats horizontally in the clouded sky above the text that is surrounded by flames, which seem to be creating the reddened area of sky behind the central figures. The woman fully extends her left arm parallel to the line of her body to hold the arm of a naked infant who floats horizontally in line with her arm. Her right hand seems to hold a fold in her gown.

component.illusobjdesc: Drawn in left profile with her back to the viewer, a young female wearing a full, flowing gown with bat-winged collar and with her hair pulled back in a bun hovers horizontally in a clouded sky. She fully extends her left arm parallel to the line of her body to hold the arm of a naked infant who floats horizontally in line with her arm. Her right hand seems to hold a fold in her gown. Her pointed right shoe is exposed.
A naked infant, one of whose extended arms is held by a female, floats horizontally in line with her arm.
Flames, or flame-like vegetation, surround the text on all sides, and seem to produce the reddish background behind the figures at the top of the plate.
Flames, or flame-like vegetation, surround the text on all sides, and seem to produce the reddish background behind the figures at the top of the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Beneath the "R" of "URIZEN" (line 6) may be a winged insect. Right of the "N" (line 6) there is a falling figure. An ornamental extension on the "D" of "Dictate" (line 12) is a quill(?). A vine-like extension on the "y" of "solitary" (line 10) divides the stanzas from one another.

component.illusobjdesc: Beneath the "R" of "URIZEN" (line 6) may be a winged insect.
Right of the "N" of "URIZEN" (line 6) is one falling figure, with its arms raised horizontally, and perhaps the suggestion of a second figure to the left of the first.
An ornamental extension on the "D" of "Dictate" (line 12) is a quill(?).
A vine-like extension on the "y" of "solitary" (line 10) separates the stanzas from one another.

lg.l: PRELUDIUM
TO
THE
BOOK OFIn Copy G, the word "FIRST" preceding "BOOK OF" was not printed.
URIZEN
Of the primeval Priests assum'd power,
When Eternals spurnd back his religion:
And gave him a place in the north,
Obscure. shadowy. void. solitary.
Eternals I hear your call gladly,
Dictate swift winged words. & fear not
To unfold your dark visions of torment.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude young man—variously identified as Los, Orc, and Urizen—with short hair, facing away from the viewer, runs right to left with his arms outstretched and legs spread. Flames envelope, and perhaps emanate from, his entire body, producing a halo or a kind of whole-body aura.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude young man—variously identified as Los, Orc, and Urizen—with short hair, facing away from the viewer, runs right to left with his arms outstretched and legs spread. Flames envelop, and perhaps emanate from, his entire body, producing a halo or a kind of whole-body aura.
Flames envelop, and perhaps emanate from, the figure's entire body, producing a halo and a kind of whole-body aura.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate, with at least one flowery stem just to the left and a stem of buds, flowers, or leaves along the bottom of the right column, also sends out tendrils that separate the two columns of text; other vines or tendrils, usually but not always continuous with the central plant, separate most of the stanzas. Other stanzas are separated by flying insects and birds, sometimes in combination with the vegetation (as between lines 44-45 and between lines 48-49).

component.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate, with at least one flowery stem just to the left and a stem of buds, flowers, or leaves along the bottom of the right column, also sends out tendrils that divide the two columns of text; other tendrils and vines, usually but not always continuous with the central plant, separate most of the stanzas and fill spaces at the ends of lines and around chapter headings. Some of these vines contain loops, e.g., the vine separating lines 10 and 11.
In the left column, a line of several flying birds divides lines 20-21; other flying birds are seen at the end of lines 36 (more birdlike than bird) and 48.
A flying insect, with other insects (or birds) beside it, separates lines 44 and 45.

lg.l: 1. Lo, a shadow of horror is risen
In Eternity! Unknown, unprolific?
Self-closd, all-repelling: what Demon
Hath form'd this abominable void
This soul-shudd'ring vacuum? Some
said
'It is Urizen", But unknown, abstracted
Brooding secret, the dark power hid.
2. Times on times he divided, & measur'd
Space by space in his ninefold darkness
Unseen, unknown: changes appeard
In his desolate mountains rifted furiousIn Copy G, "In his," in ink, emends the etched word "Like."
By the black winds of perturbation
3. For he strove in battles dire
In unseen conflictions with shapes
Bred from his forsaken wilderness.
Of beast, bird, fish, serpent & element
Combustion. blast, vapour and cloud.
4. Dark revolving in silent activity:
Unseen in tormenting passions;
An activity unknown and horrible;
A self-contemplating shadow.
In enormous labours occupied
5. But Eternals beheld his vast forests:
Age on ages he lay, clos'd, unknown.
Brooding shut in the deep; all avoid
The petrific abominable chaos
6. His cold horrors silent. dark Urizen
Prepar'd; his ten thousands of thunders
Rang'd in gloom'd array stretch. out across
The dread world. & the rolling of wheels
As of swelling seas, sound in his clouds
In his hills of stor'd snows, in his mountains
Of hail & ice; voices of terror.
Are heard, like thunders of autumn,
When the cloud blazes over the harvests
-tionIn Copy G, the "n" in "-tion" is very lightly printed.
1. Earth was not: nor globes of attrac-
The will of the Immortal expanded
Or contracted his all flexible senses,
Death was not, but eternal life sprung
2 The sound of a trumpet the heavens
Awoke & vast clouds of blood roll'd
Round the dim rocks of Urizen so nam'd
That solitary one in Immensity
Shrill the trumpet: & myriads of EterAt the beginning of this line, the section number and period—"3."—were not printed in Copy G.
-nity

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man, presumably Urizen, with long, flowing white hair and beard crouches, supporting himself with his left knee and both hands on the ground. He is positioned at the mouth of a cave or in a cleft in a rock whose weight seems to bear down on his head and shoulders.

component.illusobjdesc: Facing forward, a nude old man, presumably Urizen, with long, flowing white hair and beard crouches, supporting himself with his left knee and both hands on the ground. His right knee and foot are prominent.
Urizen appears to be crouching in the mouth of a cave or a cleft in a rock surface.
The mottled coloring of the rocks may suggest lichens.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned old man with long white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, faces the viewer squarely. From a sitting or squatting position, with arms raised horizontally, he holds the top corners of a large book that opens toward the viewer, revealing a text of indecipherable marks. The text lies largely in shadow. An area of light surrounding the book and the old man becomes a dark halo, broken by beams of light, above his head. The design may depict the moment when the Eternals "saw his pale visage / Emerge from the darkness; his hand / . . . unclasping / The Book of brass" (Erdman page 72; plate not in this copy).

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned old man with long white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, faces the viewer directly. From a sitting or squatting position, with arms raised horizontally, he holds the top corners of a large book. An area of light surrounding the book and the old man becomes a halo above his head. His left leg is bent at the knee and drawn up toward his chest.

Urizen holds the top corners of a large book, perhaps the Book of Brass (Erdman page 72; plate not in this copy), that opens toward the viewer, revealing a text of indecipherable marks. The text lies largely in shadow. An area of light surrounding the book becomes a halo above Urizen's head.
The text of Urizen's book lies largely in shadow.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate sends out leaves and tendrils that divide the two columns of text; other vines or tendrils, sometimes extensions of the central plant, divide some of the stanzas. Miscellaneous birds, serpents, and human figures occupy spaces left between stanzas and at the ends of lines.

component.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate sends out leaves and tendrils that divide the two columns of text; other tendrils and vines, sometimes extensions of the central plant, divide some of the stanzas, appearing most notably between lines 12 and 13. A very long leaf takes up the space at the end of line 22.

Miscellaneous birds occupy the spaces between stanzas and at the ends of lines. In the left column, a tiny bird or insect appears between lines 3 and 4. A larger bird with a forked tail flies at the ends of lines 6-8. A line of nine tiny birds divides lines 17 and 18. Two birds divide lines 41 and 42.

At the ends of lines 19-20 there are five hovering figures. The two on the right seem to be in the "flames of Eternal fury" (line 20). The first and third figures from the left (and possibly the other three) have their arms extended.
The two hovering figures on the right at the end of line 20 seem to be in the "flames of Eternal fury" (line 20).
Between lines 31 and 32 are two hovering figures. The one on the left is gowned and holds its arms extended toward the other.
Between lines 31 and 32 are two hovering figures. The one on the right is running with its arms raised horizontally.
A long serpent with open mouth faces right at the end of line 43.
The tail of the "y" on "fury" at the end of line 20 turns into an especially squiggly— not exactly loopy—and vigorous separation between lines 20 and 21.

lg.l: In living creations appear'd
In the flames of eternal fury,
3. Sund'ring. dark'ning, thund'ring!
Rent away with a terrible crash
Eternity roll'd wide apart
Wide asunder rolling
Mountainous all around
Departing; departing: departing;
Leaving ruinous fragments of life
Hanging frowning cliffs & all between
An ocean of voidness unfathomable.
4. The roaring fires ran o'er the heav'ns
In whirlwinds & cataracts of blood
And o'er the dark desarts of Urizen
Fires pour thro' the void on all sides
On Urizens self-begotten armies
5. But no light from the fires, all was
darkness
In the flames of Eternal fury
6. In fierce anguish & quenchless
flames
-ging
To the desarts and rocks he ran ra-
To hide, but he could not, combining
He dug mountains & hills in vast strength.In Copy G, the first letter of "He" in lines 26 and 27 was changed from a lower-case "h" to an upper-case "H."
He piled them in incessant labour,
In howlings & pangs & fierce madness
Long periods in burning fires labouring
Till hoary, and age-broke, and aged,
In despair and the shadows of death.
7. And a roof vast petrific around,
On all sides he fram'd: like a womb;
Where thousands of rivers in veins
Of blood pour down the mountains to cool
The eternal fires beating without
From Eternals; & like a black globe
View'd by sons of Eternity, standing
On the shore of the infinite ocean
Like a human heart strugling & beating
The vast world of Urizen appear'd.
8. And Los round the dark globe of
Urizen,
Kept watch for Eternals to confine,
The obscure separation alone;
For Eternity stood wide apart.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, floats or swims on his back in dark water cut horizontally by waves. Alternatively, he may be rising to the surface of the water from beneath. The design may depict Urizen's report that he "repell'd / The vast waves, & arose on the waters / A wide world of solid obstruction" (Erdman page 72; plate not in this copy). His arms are raised at 135 degrees and his knees are drawn up toward his chest; his feet appear to leave a wake at lower left.

component.illusobjdesc: Seen from above, a nude old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, floats or swims on his back in dark water. Alternatively, he may be rising to the surface of the water from beneath. His arms are raised at 135 degrees and his knees are drawn up toward his chest. His hair and beard stream out into the water, and his feet appear to leave a wake at lower left.
Urizen floats in what appears to be dark water cut horizontally by waves. His feet appear to leave a wake at lower left.

objnote.p: As printed fragments indicate, two lines of text, between lines 11 and 12, have been deleted from the copperplate. Erdman notes that these lines are "almost legible in Copy B" (page 805).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three nude male figures with serpents coiled around their bodies fall downward through, and into, flames. The figure on the left faces away and clutches his head in his hands. The figure on the right also clutches his head in his hands, but he falls backward with his face up rather than down and with his body, the most contracted of the three figures, facing the viewer. The figure in the middle faces outward with his arms raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees. The serpent's left-facing head and upper body encircle the middle figure's head, and the serpent's tail similarly encircles his feet and then terminates in small coils. Two mysterious faces, perhaps of animals, appear in the flames on each side of the torso of the middle figure.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male figure in the coils of a serpent falls downward through, and into, flames. He faces away and clutches his head in his hands.
A nude male figure in the coils of a serpent falls downward through, and into, flames. He falls backward with his face up and with his body somewhat contracted and facing the viewer.

A nude male figure in the coils of a serpent falls downward through, and into, flames. He faces outward, toward the viewer, with his arms raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees; his left foot is prominently displayed. The shape made by the serpent's head and upper body suggest a halo.
A serpent coils around the body of a nude male.

A serpent, facing left, coils around the body of a nude male. With jaws open and tongue visible, the serpent's left-facing head and upper body encircle the figure's head, and the serpent's tail similarly encircles the feet and then terminates in small coils.
A serpent coils around the body of a nude male.

Two mysterious faces appear in the flames on each side of the torso of the middle figure. The face on the left may be of a male with a beard, or of some animal, perhaps a lion. The face on the right also resembles a lion.
Vertical flames are bright in the central area of the design and dark on either side. At the bottom flames lick up toward the human figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The two columns are divided by a central vine. A line of birds appears between lines 3 and 4 to divide stanzas 8 and 9. Flames(?) (covering lines deleted from the plate) divide stanzas 10 and 11 (lines 11-12).

component.illusobjdesc: A line of five birds appears between lines 3 and 4 in the left column to divide stanzas 8 and 9.
The two columns are divided by a central tendril or vine with one branch, perhaps with leaves or blossoms, extending left at the ends of lines 6-9.
Flames(?) (covering lines deleted from the plate) divide stanzas 10 and 11.

lg.l: As the stars are apart from the earth
9. Los wept howling around the dark
Demon:
And cursing his lot for in anguish.
Urizen was rent from his side:
And a fathomless void for his feet:
And intense fires for his dwelling.
10. But Urizen laid in a stony sleep
Unorganiz'd. rent from Eternity
11, The Eternals said; What is this? Death
Urizen is a clod of clay.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude man is seen from behind facing downward. His white hair streams back (or up) toward his feet, while a beard, barely discernible from above along the edge of his jaw, makes it likely that this is Urizen. His body and left leg arc to the left; his right leg is bent toward the viewer, exposing the sole of his right foot. His arms are drawn back and his elbows are bent, as if the weight of his body is resting on his hands, which in turn are braced on what may be rock, earth, or clouds at the bottom of the design. His lower body is partly enveloped in a filmy, semi-transparent substance, perhaps clouds. His position, along with his streaming hair and beard, suggests falling, floating, or hovering.

component.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude man is seen from behind facing downward. His white hair streams back (or up) toward his feet, while a beard, barely discernible along the edge of his jaw, makes it likely that this is Urizen, though he may be Los. His body and left leg arc to the left; his right leg is bent toward the viewer, exposing the sole of his right foot. His arms are drawn back and his elbows are bent, as if the weight of his body is resting on his hands. His lower body is partly enveloped in a filmy, semi-transparent substance, perhaps clouds. His position, along with his streaming hair and beard, suggests falling, floating, or hovering.
A surface of stone, earth, or clouds seems to support the weight of the figure.
A filmy, semi-transparent substance, perhaps clouds, or Blake's attempt to represent air, partly envelops the lower body of the figure.
The figure may be swimming in a body of water.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude man, perhaps Los, kneels in flames that swirl about him as he clutches his head with crossed arms and hands, right hand to left side of face, left hand to right side. His mouth and eyes are wide open as if in agony or terror, perhaps depicting the moment when "Los howld in a dismal stupor" (line 2).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude man, perhaps Los, kneels in flames that swirl about him as he clutches his head with crossed arms and hands, right hand to left side of face, left hand to right side. His mouth and eyes are wide open as if in agony or terror.
Swirling flames surround a male figure, perhaps Los.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central flame-like vine (or vine-like flame) divides the two columns, and its tendrils divide stanzas and fill some of the spaces at the ends of lines. The tendrils between lines 4 and 5 and between lines 9 and 10 are especially vigorous.

lg.l: 12: Los howld in a dismal stupor,
Groaning! gnashing! groaning!
Till the wrenching apart was healed
13: But the wrenching of Urizen
heal'd not
Cold, featureless. flesh or clay
Rifted with direful changes
He lay in a dreamless night
14: Till Los rouz'd his his fires
affrighted
At the formless unmeasurable
death.

In the context of the gestation and birth metaphors of the text, the skeleton's position may suggest a fetus.

lg.l: 1: Los smitten with astonish-
Frightend at the hurtling bones
2; And at the surging sulphure-
-ous
Perturbed Immortal mad raging
3: In whirlwinds & pitch & nitre
Round the furious limbs of Los
4; And Los formed nets & gins
And threw the nets round about
5: He watch'd in shuddring fear
The dark changes & bound every
change
With rivets of iron & brass;
6, And these were the changes
of Urizen,

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits in a contracted position with knees drawn up to his chest, arms down at his sides. His wrists and ankles are shackled with massive fetters and chains; the chains that connect left-wrist shackle to left-ankle shackle and right-wrist shackle to right-ankle shackle are visible. His eyes are closed and tears flow down each cheek. A dark halo broken by beams of bright light, as if from the sun, encircles his head. The background suggests a cave or other stony area.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude man seen from behind stands in a cave-like opening in a wall of stone. He stands on what may be a hilly peninsula or island of earth or rock (there is the suggestion of water in front of it). His left leg is placed forward and bent at the knee and his right leg extended behind, as if positioned to support the weight of the massive rock above. His arms, accordingly, are raised horizontally and bent upward at the elbows, in a position to support weight from above. His head and hands are hidden by the rock; alternatively, he may be headless.

lg.l: 1. Ages on ages roll'd over him!
In stony sleep ages roll'd over him!
Like a dark waste stretching chang'able
By earthquakes riv'n, belching sullen
fires
On ages roll'd ages in ghastly
Sick torment; around him in whirlwinds
Of darkness the eternal Prophet howl'd
Beating still on his rivets of iron
Pouring sodor of iron; dividing
The horrible night into watches,
2. And Urizen (so his eternal name)
His prolific delight obscurd more & more
In dark secresy hiding in surgeing
Sulphureous fluid his phantasies
The Eternal Prophet heavd the dark
bellows.
And turn'd restless the tongs; and the
hammer
Incessant beat; forging chains new & new
Numb'ring with links, hours days & years
3 The eternal mind bounded began to roll
Eddies of wrath ceaseless round & round
And the sulphureous foam. surgeing thick
Settled, a lake, bright. & shining clear:
White as the snow on the mountains cold
4. Forgetfulness. dumbness. necessity!
In chains of the mind locked up,
Like fetters of ice shrinking together.
Disorganiz'd. rent from Eternity.
Los beat on his fetters of iron:
And heated his furnaces & pour'd
Iron sodor and sodor of brass
5. Restless turnd the immortal inchain'd
Heaving dolorous! anguish'd! unbearable
Till a roof shaggy wild inclos'd
In an orb, his fountain of thought.
6. In a horrible dreamful slumber;
Like the linked infernal chain;
A vast Spine writh'd in torment
Upon the winds; shooting pain'd
Ribs, like a bending cavern
And bones of solidness, froze,
Over all his nerves of joy.
And a first Age passed over,
And a state of dismal woe,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two nude male figures, with tormented expressions and their legs drawn up toward their chests, sit in or in front of a wall of upward-swirling flames. (The background of the text above is washed to suggest smoke from these flames.) The dark and emaciated, virtually skeletal, figure on the left looks upward while holding his arms at his side and resting his hands on his knees. The figure on the right sits with head tilted back and his right shoulder twisted around to allow both hands to rest on the ground on one side. If the figure on the right is Los, the round object at bottom right is probably one end of the "great hammer" that "fell from his hand" when he "shrunk from his task" (Plate 15, lines 23-25) after putting Urizen in chains. The figure on the left, if Urizen, has no chains in this copy.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male with tormented expression and legs drawn up toward his chest sits in or near a wall of upward-swirling flames. The dark and emaciated, virtually skeletal, figure looks upward while holding his arms at his side and resting his hands on his knees. If he is Urizen after Los has chained him, he has no chains in this copy.

Two nude males sit in or near a wall of upward-swirling flames.

lg.l: 7. From the caverns of his jointed Spine,
Down sunk with fright a red
Round globe hot burning deep
Deep down into the Abyss;
Panting: Conglobing, Trembling
Shooting out ten thousand branches
Around his solid bones.
And a second Age passed over,
And a state of dismal woe.
8. In harrowing fear rolling round;
His nervous brain shot branches
Round the branches of his heart
On high into two little orbs
And fixed in two little caves
Hiding carefully from the wind.
His Eyes beheld the deep.
And a third Age passed over;
And a state of dismal woe,
9. The pangs of hope began.
In heavy pain striving, struggling.
Two Ears in close volutions.
From beneath his orbs of vision
Shot spiring out. and petrified
As they grew, And a fourth Age passIn Copy G, the letters "ed" at the end of "passed" did not print.
And a state of dismal woe.
10. In ghastly torment sick;
Hanging upon the wind;

texthead.l: Urizen C:V.In Copy G, the number "1" preceding "Urizen" has been erased.

lg.l: Two Nostrils bent down to the deep.
And a fifth Age passed over;
And a state of dismal woe,
11. In ghastly torment sick;
Within his ribs bloated round.
A craving Hungry Cavern:
Thence arose his channeld Throat,
And like a red flame a Tongue
Of thirst & of hunger appeard.
And a sixth Age passed over:The first letter of "Age" was written in acid-resist as both a lower-case "a" and an upper-case "A." Both letters were etched, and both print in Copy G.
And a state of dismal woe.
12. Enraged & stifled with torment
He threw his right Arm to the north
His left Arm to the south
Shooting out in anguish deep.
And his Feet stampd the nether Abyss
In trembling & howling & dismay.
And a seventh Age passed over;
And a state of dismal woe.
1. In terrors Los shrunk from his
task;
His great hammer fell from his hand:
His fires beheld, and sickening.
Hid their strong limbs in smoke.
For with noises ruinous loud;
With hurtlings & clashings & groans
The Immortal endur'd his chains,
Tho' bound in a deadly sleep.
2, All the myriads of Eternity:
All the wisdom & joy of life:
Roll like a sea around him.
Except what his little orbs
Of sight by degrees unfold.
3. And now his eternal life
Like a dream was obliterated
4, Shudd'ring, the Eternal Prophet smote
With a stroke, from his north to south
region
The bellows & hammer are silent now
A nerveless silence, his prophetic voice
Siez'd; a cold solitude & dark void
The Eternal Prophet & Urizen clos'd
5, Ages on ages rolld over them
Cut off from life & light frozen
Into horrible forms of deformity
Los suffer'd his fires to decay
Then he look'd back with anxious desire
But the space undivided by existence
Struck horror into his soul.
6, Los wept obscur'd with mourning:
His bosom earthquak'd with sighs,
He saw Urizen deadly black,
In his chains bound, & Pity began.
7, In anguish dividing & dividing
For pity divides the soul
In pangs eternity on eternity
Life in cataracts pourd down his
cliffs
The void shrunk the lymph into Nerves
Wand'ring wide on the bosom of night
And left a round globe of blood
Trembling upon the Void

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four figures who may be the Eternals, three male and one either male or female, are suspended, as if in a cloud, over a green area that looks like the earth below, its surface curved like part of a globe. They may be erecting a tent between their world and Urizen's (Plate 19, lines 3-12). Between the group of figures above and the globe below are streaks of cloud and light that may suggest sunrise or sunset. Clockwise from the right the figures are: (1) the head of a male with long, white, flowing hair and beard and closed eyes; (2) a male, naked from the waist up, reaching down toward the earth with his left arm and hand, his fingers emitting streams of some substance; (3) the head of a second male with long, curly hair and beard and closed eyes; (4) the head of a youthful boy or girl. The garments of all the figures seem to swirl together behind them; figures (1) and (2) may be clothed together in one garment. At the top left of the design are the head, neck, and wings of an eagle in profile.

component.illusobjdesc: The head, neck, and wings of an eagle are seen in profile.
The head of a youthful boy or girl looks down toward the earth, perhaps with eyes closed.
The head of a male with long, curly hair and beard and eyes closed appears just left of the central figure.

A male, naked from the waist up, braced on his right arm, bends forward and reaches down toward the earth with his left arm; his fingers emit streams of some substance. His clothing, more drapery than gown, swirls out behind him; it appears to be the same garment as the one that clothes the figure on the far right. His hair is short and somewhat curly.

The head of a man with long, flowing white beard and closed eyes appears right of the central figure. The end of his beard seems to touch the earth below and to combine with the substance emitted by the fingers of the figure to the left.
Four figures hover over a curved area of earth, like part of the globe.
Four figures hover in a cloud-like area above the earth in lighting that suggests sunrise or sunset.
From the central figure's fingers streams a substance that may be the fabric of the tent erected by the Eternals, its curtains, flesh, or Blakean streams of gore.
From the central figure's fingers streams a substance that may be the fabric of the tent erected by the Eternals, its curtains, flesh, or Blakean streams of gore.

A flower, independent of the central vine, forms from an extension of the "d" at the end of "appear'd" (line 10). A single bird flies above "a winterly" in line 6.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine separates the two columns of text from one another. lg.l: Thus the Eternal Prophet was divided
Before the death image of Urizen
For in changeable clouds and darkness
In a winterly night beneath,
The Abyss of Los stretch'd immense:
And now seen. now obscur'd to the eyes
Of Eternals, the visions remote
Of the dark seperation appear'd.
As glasses discover Worlds
In the endless Abyss of space,
So the expanding eyes of Immortals
Beheld the dark visions of Los,
And the globe of life blood trembling.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A fully-gowned figure with long hair, perhaps Los creating Enitharmon (or Enitharmon herself), bends forward toward the viewer over a large globe that occupies the bottom half of the design. His head is down, making his face invisible and exposing his back to the viewer. He raises his arms at 135 degrees and holds his hands vertically to his head and perhaps over his ears. Rivulets of a bright substance, perhaps fire or blood, crisscross the figure's back, surround the globe, and seem to fuse his hair and lower body with the globe. The design may depict the "globe of life blood" that "trembled / Branching out into roots" to embody a "female form trembling and pale . . . the first female, now separate" (Plate 18, lines 3-12).

component.illusobjdesc: A fully-gowned figure with long hair bends forward toward the viewer over a large globe. His head is down, making his face invisible and exposing his back to the viewer. He raises his arms horizontally and holds his hands to his head and perhaps over his ears. Rivulets of a bright substance—perhaps fire, blood, or sinews—crisscross the figure's back, surround the globe, and seem to fuse his hair and lower body with the globe. He may be Los creating Enitharmon (Plate 18, lines 3-10) or Enitharmon herself.

A figure bends forward over a large globe that occupies the bottom half of the design. The globe appears to be fused to the figure by organic strands that seem to be hair, blood, nerves, and fire simultaneously. This may be the "globe of life blood" (Plate 16, line 15).

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male with curly hair, Los, stands in the midst of flames. His legs are spread, his genitals exposed, and his arms raised horizontally. In his left hand he holds a large hammer, which rests on what may be a pillar or anvil. He rests his right hand on a stone or broken pillar.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male with curly hair, Los, stands in the midst of flames. His head is bent back and to the left. His legs are spread, his genitals exposed, and his arms raised horizontally. In his left hand he holds a large hammer. He rests his right hand on a stone or broken pillar.
Los is holding a large hammer in his left hand.

Los's hammer may be resting on a stone pillar or an anvil. Other such objects appear below his left forearm and behind the shaft of the hammer. His right arm and hand also rest upon what appear to be blocks of stone. These may all be part of a ruined wall or building.
Los stands in the midst of flames.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine separates the two columns of text from one another. Its serpentine or flame- like extensions fill the spaces at the ends of two short lines. An independent vine forms an extension of the "W" at the beginning of line 15 and wraps around the end of line 14.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine separates the two columns of text from one another. Its serpentine or flame- like extensions fill the spaces at the ends of two short lines to the left. An independent vine forms an extension of the "W" at the beginning of line 15 and wraps around the end of line 14.

lg.l: 8. The globe of life blood trembled
Branching out into roots;
Fib'rous, writhing upon the winds:
Fibres of blood. milk and tears:
In pangs. eternity on eternity,
At length in tears & cries imbodied
A female form trembling and pale
Waves before his deathy face
9, All Eternity shudderd at sight
Of the first female now separate
Pale as a cloud of snow
Waving before the face of Los
10. Wonder, awe, fear, astonishment,
Petrify the eternal myriads;
At the first female form now separate

illustration.illusobjdesc: On the left a nude female with long hair stands or runs in smoke and flames with her body arched and twisted sharply to the left, her right foot forward, and her only visible hand raised to her forehead. On the ground beside her to the right, out of the flames, sits a second nude figure, probably male, in a contracted position with his legs doubled up beneath him and his hands clutching his head. The two figures may be Los and Enitharmon: "the first female now separate / Pale as a cloud of snow / Waving before the face of Los" (Plate 18, lines 12-14).

component.illusobjdesc: On the left a nude female with long hair, perhaps Enitharmon, stands or runs in smoke and flames with her body arched and twisted sharply to the left, her right foot forward, and her only visible hand raised to her forehead. Her mouth is open.

On the ground to the right, out of the flames, sits a nude figure with long hair, probably male, perhaps Los, in a contracted position with his legs doubled up beneath him and his hands clutching his head.
The female figure stands in flames and smoke.
Los appears to be kneeling on a grassy surface. Arching over him, following the general contours of his body, a tree branch is discernible against the dark, smoky background.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine or flame-like leaves and tendrils help fill the spaces at ends of short lines to the left of center. One tendril fills the space between stanzas 10-11 (lines 2-3) and another helps fill the space around the heading of chapter 6 (line 13). At the top, above both columns of text, the vine forks left and right to become the lower edge of the vegetation in the large design above. In the right column a few tendrils independent of the central vine, several generated as extensions of letters in the text, fill spaces similarly. The serpentine extension of the "t" in "serpent" (line 31) and the loopy extension of the "s" at the end of "resistless" (line 49) are notable. Flanking the chapter 6 heading (line 13), two figures hover horizontally, their arms extended.

component.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine or flame-like leaves and tendrils (a few generated independently as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces at ends of short lines to the left of center. One tendril fills the space between stanzas 10-11 (lines 2-3) and another helps fill the space around the heading of chapter 6 (line 13). At the top, above both columns of text, the vine forks left and right to become the lower edge of the vegetation in the large design above. In the right column a few tendrils independent of the central vine, several generated as extensions of letters in the text, fill spaces similarly. The serpentine extension of the "t" in "serpent" (line 31) and the loopy extension of the "s" at the end of "resistless" (line 49) are notable.
Flanking the chapter 6 heading (line 13), two figures hover horizontally. They face the text, their arms extended. A flag-like piece of drapery floats behind the figure on the left.
Flanking the chapter 6 heading (line 13) are two hovering figures. They face the text, extending their arms, with bodies horizontal. The figure on the right may have its legs spread.

lg.l: They call'd her Pity, and fled
11. "Spread a Tent. with strong cur-
-tains around them
"Let cords & stakes bind in the Void
That Eternals may no more behold them"
12, They began to weave curtains of
darkness
They erected large pillars round the Void
With golden hooks fastend in the pillars
With infinite labour the Eternals
A woof wove. and called it Science
1. But Los saw the Female & pitied
He embrac'd her, she wept, she refus'd
In perverse and cruel delight
She fled from his arms, yet he followd
2. Eternity shudder'd when they saw,
Man begetting his likeness,
On his own divided image.
3. A time passed over, the Eternals
Began to erect the tent;
When Enitharmon sick,
Felt a Worm within her womb.
4. Yet helpless it lay like a Worm
In the trembling womb
To be moulded into existence
5, All day the worm lay on her bosom
All night within her womb
The worm lay till it grew to a ser-
-pent
With dolorous hissings & poisons
Round Enitharmons loins folding,
6, Coild within Enitharmons womb
The serpent grew casting its scales.
With sharp pangs the hissings began
To change to a grating cry,
Many sorrows and dismal throes.
Many forms of fish, bird & beast
Brought forth an Infant form
Where was a worm before.
7. The Eternals their tent finished
Alarm'd with these gloomy visions
When Enitharmon groaning
Produc'd a man Child to the light.
8. A shriek ran thro' Eternity:
And a paralytic stroke;
At the birth of the Human shadow,
9, Delving earth in his resistless
way:
Howling, the Child with fierce flames
Issu'd from Enitharmon.
10. The Eternals, closed the tent
They beat down the stakes the cords

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the center of a burst of flames, a nude, male infant or child falls with head downward and limbs outspread toward what may be an area of water or darkness below. The design may depict the birth of Orc: "Delving earth in his resistless / way: / Howling, the Child with fierce flames / Issu'd from Enitharmon" (Plate 19, lines 49-52).

component.illusobjdesc: At the center of a burst of flames, a nude, male infant or child, perhaps Orc, with head downward and limbs outspread, falls toward what may be an area of water or darkness below. His hair is short and curly.
A child falls at the center of a burst of flames. The bottom right corner of the text just above the central burst is in flames as well.
A child falls into an area of what may be water or darkness.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with an unusual number of tendrils tangled in the central area separates the columns of text. Its serpentine or flame-like leaves and tendrils (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, and often generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between stanzas (from top left, stanzas 10-11, 1-2, 2-3, 5-6, 7-8, 9-10), around all three of the chapter headings (at the top center and in each column), and around short lines. Some of the extensions of letters are extravagant, especially (in the right column) the "e" of "the" in line 31 and the "U" of "Urizen" in line 36. In the margin at lower right, in lieu of vines, flames are extended upward from the large design below into the spaces at the ends of lines that begin chapter 8.

texthead.l: Urizen C: VII In Copy G, the number "1" preceding "Urizen" has been erased.

lg.l: Stretch'd for a work of eternity:
No more Los beheld Eternity,
11. In his hands he siez'd the infant
He bathed him in springs of sorrow
He gave him to Enitharmon.
1. They named the child Orc, he grew
Fed with milk of Enitharmon
2, Los awoke her; O sorrow & pain!
A tight'ning girdle grew.
Around his bosom, In sobbings
He burst the girdle in twain,
But still another girdle
Opressd his bosom, In sobbings
Again he burst it, Again
Another girdle succeeds
The girdle was form'd by day;
By night was burst in twain.
3. These falling down on the rock
Into an iron Chain
In each other link by link lock'd
4. They took Orc to the top of a
mountain.
O how Enitharmon wept!
They chain'd his young limbs to the
rock
With the Chain of Jealousy
Beneath Urizens deathful shadow
5, The dead heard the voice of the
child
And began to awake from sleep
All things, heard the voice of the child
And began to awake to life.
6. And Urizen craving with hunger
Stung with the odours of Nature
Explor'd his dens around
7. He form'd a line & a plummet
To divide the Abyss beneath.
He form'd a dividing rule:
8, He formed scales to weigh:
He formed massy weights;
He formed a brazen quadrant:
He formed golden compasses
And began to explore the Abyss
And he planted a garden of fruits
9. But Los encircled Enitharmon
With fires of Prophecy
From the sight of Urizen & Orc.
10. And she bore an enormous race
1. Urizen explor'd his dens
Mountain, moor, & wilderness,
With a globe of fire lighting his
journey
A fearful journey. annoy'd
By cruel enormities; forms

illustration.illusobjdesc: A tightly arranged group of three figures stands against a rocky cliff, perhaps covered by indeterminate vegetation, with a rising or setting sun just above the horizon. The figures, from left to right, are (1) a nude woman with long hair who with her right arm is embracing, while looking down toward, (2) a nude child with short hair, probably male, seen from behind, who embraces the female with both arms; and (3) a bearded nude male, likewise looking down toward the child. A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (Plate 20, line 29), hangs down the length of his body; its ends disappear under his arm and at his feet. His left hand is not visible; with his right he holds a large hammer that rests on a pedestal or anvil. The trio likely represents Enitharmon and Los with the child Orc.

component.illusobjdesc: Enitharmon, a nude woman with long hair, stands in contrapposto, right foot forward, while embracing and looking down toward Orc. Her head seems to touch the head of Los on the right.
Orc, a nude and probably male child with short, curly hair seen from behind standing in contrapposto, embraces his mother Enitharmon with both arms raised and head up.

Los, a bearded nude male standing in contrapposto, looks down toward Orc. His head appears to touch the head of Enitharmon, who stands close beside him. A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (Plate 20, line 29) hangs down the length of his body. His left hand is not visible; with his right he holds a large hammer that rests on a pedestal or anvil, behind which he places his left foot.
A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (Plate 20, line 29) hangs down the length of Los's body; its ends disappear under his arm and at his feet.
Los holds a large hammer vertically. It rests on a pedestal or anvil.
Los's hammer rests on a pedestal or anvil.
Three figures stand against a cliff, with a rising or setting sun just above the horizon.
Three figures stand against a cliff, perhaps covered with indeterminate vegetation.
Three figures stand against a cliff, perhaps covered with indeterminate vegetation.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a dark, mountainous landscape opening onto an area of blue sky, a fully gowned old man with long, flowing beard, probably Urizen, strides vigorously to the right. His left arm extends forward with the palm of the hand vertical. With his right hand by his side he holds a sun-like globe that emits dark beams. At bottom right the head and front legs of a lion appear in profile. The illustration seems to depict the episode in which "Urizen explor'd his dens / Mountain, moor & wilderness / With a globe of fire lighting his / journey" (Plate 20, lines 53-56).

component.illusobjdesc: Urizen, as a fully gowned old man with long, flowing beard, strides vigorously to the right. His left arm is extended with his palm vertical. With his right hand by his side he holds a sun-like globe.
A dark, mountainous landscape opens onto an area of blue sky.
A dark, mountainous landscape opens onto an area of blue sky.
The head and front legs of a lion with long mane appear in profile.
With his right hand by his side Urizen holds a sun-like globe that emits spiky beams of light.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine or flame-like or, in one instance between stanzas 4 and 5 (lines 31-32), loopy tendrils and leaves (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, often generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between all the stanzas on this plate, around the chapter heading at top center, and around short lines. Some of the extensions of letters are particularly extravagant, especially the "n" of "Fuzon" in line 21. The extensions of the central vine that sprout left and right below the text and around Urizen's head have shapes that may suggest serpents with (on the right) open mouths. Four flying birds help fill the space between stanzas 1 and 2 (lines 3-4).

Some of the extensions of letters are extravagant, especially the "n" of "Fuzon" in line 21. The extensions of the central vine that sprout oddly to the left and right below the text and around Urizen's head have shapes that may suggest serpents with (on the right) open mouths.
Four flying birds help fill the space between stanzas 1 and 2 (lines 3-4).
The extensions of the central vine that sprout oddly to the left and right below the text and around Urizen's head have shapes that may suggest serpents with (on the right) open mouths.

lg.l: Of life on his forsaken mountains
2. And his world teemd vast enormities
Frightning: faithless; fawning
Portions of life; similitudes
Of a foot, or a hand, or a head
Or a heart, or an eye. they swam mis
-chevous
Dread terrors! delighting in blood
3, Most Urizen sicken'd to see
His eternal creations appear
Sons & daughters of sorrow on mountains
Weeping! wailing! first Thiriel appear'd
Astonish'd at his own existence
Like a man from a cloud born, & Utha
From the waters emerging, laments!
Grodna rent the deep earth howling
Amaz'd! his heavens immense cracks
Like the ground parch'd with heat; then
Fuzon
Flam'd out! first begotten, last born.
All his eternal sons in like manner
His daughters from green herbs & cattle
From monsters, & worms of the pit.
4. He in darkness clos'd, view'd all his
race
And his soul sicken'd! he curs'd
Both sons & daughters; for he saw
That no flesh nor spirit could keep
His iron laws one moment.
5. For he saw that life liv'd upon
death

illustration.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned male, perhaps Urizen, hovers or strides with his face away from the viewer and his right foot trailing visibly below his gown. He holds his hands, fingers spread, beside his face as if looking through an opening or pushing against an object. A halo of reddish light surrounds his head.

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned male, perhaps Urizen, hovers or perhaps strides with his face away from the viewer and his right foot trailing visibly below his gown. He holds his hands, palms vertical and fingers spread, beside his face as if looking through an opening or pushing against an object.
A halo of reddish light, perhaps surrounded by swirling clouds, encircles the figure's head. The object he pushes against may be a cloud or large stone.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four human figures, probably representing the first four sons of Urizen, inhabit a compartmented landscape of sea, land, sky, and heavens. These sons of Urizen correspond to the classical elements of fire, air, earth, and water: "first Thiriel appear'd . . . Like a man from a cloud born, & Utha / From the waters emerging . . . Grodna rent the deep earth howling . . . then Fuzon / Flam'd out" (Plate 22, lines 14-22). Clockwise from the top: (1) Fire/Fuzon: A figure in flames, probably male, hovers horizontally, facing out toward the viewer with arms raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees. His position and the curved lower edge of the space he occupies suggest the sun. (2) Air/Thiriel: Just below Fire, with nude body in an upward curve that reinforces the suggestion of a sun above, hovers a second figure, apparently male, with his hands raised to his chest and palms turned out. A halo surrounds his head. Between these upper two figures and the lower two is a horizontal line of cloud. (3) Earth/Grodna: At lower right crouches a nude male with short hair, head up, mouth open, and hands on the ground. He seems to be emerging from the earth, represented by a wave- washed island or peninsula of land. (4) Water/Utha: At lower left, the upward-looking head of a long-haired figure of uncertain sex, but apparently male, emerges from the water. At the horizon is an area of light edged with beams that suggests another sun, this one rising or setting.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure in flames (with flame-like hair), probably male, hovers horizontally, facing out toward the viewer with arms and hands upraised between the horizontal and 135 degrees, palms out. His mouth is open. He apparently represents one of the first sons of Urizen, Fuzon, and the classical element fire. The curved shape delimited by the top two figures suggests the sun.
Flames envelop a hovering male figure, Fuzon/fire. Their shape helps to suggest the sun, though there is another sun at the horizon below.

Just below the figure of Fuzon/fire, with nude body in an upward curve that reinforces the suggestion of a sun above, hovers a figure apparently male, with short, curly hair, mouth open, and hands raised, palms out. A halo surrounds his head. He apparently represents one of the first sons of Urizen, Thiriel, and the classical element air.
A line of cloud divides the top two figures from the bottom two.
An area of sky cut by a horizontal cloud is the transitional zone between fire and air (above) and water and earth (below).

A nude male with short hair, head up, mouth open, and hands on the ground crouches, positioned as if emerging from the earth. He apparently represents one of the first sons of Urizen, Grodna, and the classical element earth.
Grodna emerges from the surface of a wave-washed island or peninsula of land.
The head of Utha emerges from an area of dark water, which washes up in waves on an area of land.
The upward-looking head of a long-haired figure of uncertain sex, but apparently male, emerges from the water. He seems to be one of the first sons of Urizen, Utha, and the classical element water.

At the horizon over the head of Utha at bottom left is a rising or setting sun suggested by an area of light edged with beams, though a second sun is suggested by the fiery shapes at the top of the design.

objnote.p: Just above the beginning of the text and centered on the plate are a few printed marks that may have been intended as a heading. If so, Blake converted these letter forms on the copperplate into mere squiggles. These marks appear in a position where Blake wrote headings on 9 other plates in *The Book of Urizen*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two nude and apparently female figures seem to be held in or emerging from the coils of giant worms or serpents; or, alternatively, the women may be the heads and upper bodies of the worms. The woman on the left, arms at her side and head tilted back, looks up and off to the left. The serpent's coil wraps around her midriff, beneath which her body disappears. The woman to the right looks in the same direction, her hands clutching her head. The scene is set in the midst of mostly indeterminate vegetation. Leafy structures edge the bottom of the design, and behind the main figures is either more vegetation in batwinged shapes or serpent wings. Just the face of a third figure, looking in the same direction as the other two, appears at the surface of the vegetation at the far right. A fourth figure, scaly, with bat wings, faces down, her head partly obscuring the upper body of the woman clutching her head. Her long hair ends in a spike or point. She is hunched over in a quasi-crawling position, a serpent coiled around her midsection. The women may be Urizen's daughters, who are born "from green herbs & cattle / From monsters, & worms of the pit" (Plate 22, lines 24-25).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude woman seen from the bosom up, arm at her side and head tilted back, looks up and off to the left. The coil of a worm or serpent wraps around her midriff, beneath which her body disappears. She is probably one of Urizen's newly born daughters.
A serpent-coiled nude woman, seen from the waist or hips up, looks up and off to the left, her hands clutching her head. She is probably one of Urizen's newly born daughters.

Just the face of a third figure, possibly female, looking in the same direction as the other two, appears amidst the coils of serpents or worms at the surface of the vegetation at the far right. She is probably one of Urizen's newly born daughters.

Flanked by the other figures, a fourth woman, scaly, with bat wings, faces down, her head partly obscuring the upper body of the female clutching her head. Her long hair ends in a spike or point. She is hunched over in a quasi-crawling position, a serpent coiled around her midsection. She is probably one of Urizen's daughters.

The scene is set in the midst of mostly indeterminate vegetation. Leafy structures edge the bottom of the design, and behind the main figures is either more vegetation in bat-winged shapes or serpent wings.
Giant worms or serpents, perhaps bat-winged, coil around human figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The interlinear designs on this plate are frequently reinforced with watercolor. A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine (even snake-like below line 49), flame- like, or loopy leaves and tendrils (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, a few of these generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between stanzas (6-7, 7-8, 8-9, 1-2, 2-3, 3-4), at the foot of the left column, and around short lines. Between stanzas 5 and 6 (lines 5-6) is a row of at least four figures, and other figures appear between stanzas 7 and 8 (lines 22-23) and between 8 and 9 (lines 25-27); in the right column, there are two figures between stanzas 1 and 2 (lines 36-37). There is a single flying bird at the end of line 49, just above a particularly snake- like tendril of vegetation that appears to be rearing its head, mouth open, toward the bird. An indistinct shape—perhaps a caterpillar or chrysalis—appears at the top of the central vine, in the center just above the text.

component.illusobjdesc: The interlinear designs on this plate are frequently reinforced with watercolor. A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine (especially between stanzas 3 and 4 in the right column), flame-like, or loopy (after lines 3 and 10) leaves and tendrils (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, a few of these generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between stanzas (6-7, 7-8, 8-9, 1-2, 2-3, 3-4), at the chapter break at the foot of the left column, and around short lines.
Between stanzas 5 and 6 (lines 5-6), after two bits of vegetation(?), is a row of four human figures. The gowned one furthest to the right is hovering horizontally, arms extended.
Between stanzas 5 and 6 (lines 5-6), after two bits of vegetation(?), is a row of four human figures. The figure second from the right runs to the left with arm raised and leg extended backward.
Between stanzas 5 and 6 (lines 5-6), after two bits of vegetation(?), is a row of four human figures. Third from the right, a figure runs to the right with leg extended backward.

Between stanzas 5 and 6 (lines 5-6), after two bits of vegetation(?), is a row of four human figures. Fourth from the right, a figure falls(?) upside down with arms raised horizontally and legs spread.
Between stanzas 7 and 8 (lines 22-23) a figure hovers with arms raised horizontally. Bits of drapery or a gown stream from the figure toward the left.
Between stanzas 1 and 2 (lines 36-37) two figures facing one another hover with their bodies horizontal and their arms extended toward one another. The legs on the right figure are spread.
Between stanzas 8 and 9 (lines 25-27) a gowned figure hovers, facing down; its arms are extended.
There is a single flying bird at the end of line 49.
An indistinct shape—perhaps a caterpillar or chrysalis—appears at the top of the central vine, in the center just above the text.

The serpentine vegetation between stanzas 3 and 4 (lines 49-50) here has a particularly snake-like appearance due to the added watercolor, which suggests a serpent with head raised, mouth open, toward the bird just above.

lg.l: The Ox in the slaughter house moans
The Dog at the wintry door
And he wept, & he called it Pity
And his tears flowed down on the winds
6. Cold he wander'd on high, over
their cities
In weeping & pain & woe!
And where-ever he wanderd in sorrows
Upon the aged heavens
A cold shadow follow'd behind him
Like a spiders web. moist, cold, & dim
Drawing out from his sorrowing soul
The dungeon-like heaven dividing.
Where ever the footsteps of Urizen
Walk'd over the cities in sorrow.
7. Till a Web dark & cold, throughout all
The tormented element stretch'd
From the sorrows of Urizens soul
And the Web is a Female in embrio
None could break the Web, no wings
of fire.
8. So twisted the cords, & so knotted
The meshes: twisted like to the
human brain
-gion
9. And all calld it, The Net of Reli-
1. Then the Inhabitants of those Cities:
Felt their Nerves change into Marrow:
And hardening Bones began
In swift diseases and torments,
In throbbings & shootings & grindings
Thro' all the coasts; till weaken'd
The Senses inward rush'd shrinking,
Beneath the dark net of infection.
2. Till the shrunken eyes clouded over
Discernd not the woven hipocrisy
But the streaky slime in their heavens
Brought together by narrowing perceptions
Appeard transparent air; for their eyes
Grew small like the eyes of a man
And in reptile forms shrinking together
Of seven feet stature they remaind
3. Six days they shrunk up from existence
And on the seventh day they rested
And they bless'd the seventh day, in sick
hope;
And forgot their eternal life
4. And their thirty cities divided
In form of a human heart
No more could they rise at will
In the infinite void, but bound down
To earth by their narrowing perceptions

illustration.illusobjdesc: Before a paneled door raked diagonally by a shadow, a child in a full gown stands facing forward with his hands raised as if in prayer. Behind him, a dog, perhaps "The Dog at the wintry door" (Plate 25, line 3), stretched out in front of the door holds its head raised vertically as if howling.

component.illusobjdesc: Before a door, a child, probably male, in a full gown stands with his hands clasped and raised as if in prayer. His mouth may be slightly open.
Behind a child, a dog—perhaps "The Dog at the wintry door" (Plate 25, line 3)—stretched out in front of the lower edge of the door holds its head raised vertically as if howling.
Before a paneled door raked diagonally by a shadow are a dog and a child. The top hinge is long (horizontally) as if supporting the weight of a large door.
The door and adjacent walls are raked diagonally by a shadow.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An old man with full gown and long, flowing white beard, presumably Urizen, sits or squats with eyes closed (or down), arms raised horizontally, and hands hanging down. His arms appear to be resting on stone surfaces to left and right. There is the suggestion of a halo—or at least an aura of light and a few beams—around his head. He is flanked by massive rope nets, one of which entangles his right shoulder. His left foot peeps out from his gown between the nets at the bottom of the design. The design probably depicts the "Web dark & cold" that "stretch'd / From the sorrows of Urizens soul / . . . / And all calld it The Net of Religion" (Plate 25, lines 17-27).

component.illusobjdesc: An old man with full gown and long, flowing white beard, presumably Urizen, sits with eyes closed (or down), arms raised horizontally, and hands hanging down. His arms appear to be resting on stone surfaces to left and right. There is the suggestion of a halo—or at least an aura of light and a few beams to the right—around his head. He is flanked by massive rope nets, one of which entangles his right shoulder. His left foot peeps out (improbably, considering the way his legs seem to be placed) from his gown between the nets at the bottom of the design. His knees are prominent.
Urizen is flanked by massive rope nets, probably the "Net of Religion" (Plate 25, line 27), one of which entangles his right shoulder.
Urizen's arms appear to be resting on stone surfaces to left and right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An unusually simple central vine divides the left from the right column of text. The vine has few extensions: one to the left of the running head at the top (line 2), a large single leaf at the end of line 10, and a sprig between stanzas 6 and 7 (lines 13-14). A few other bits of vegetation, independent of the central vine, are notable: a serpentine or flame-like tendril in the top right corner and an elaborate extension of the initial "T" in "The End" (after line 26). At the foot of the column is an outstretched corpse(?).

component.illusobjdesc: An outstretched corpse lies supine at the foot of the second column of verse.

An unusually simple central vine divides the left from the right column of text. The vine has few extensions: one to the left of the running head at the top, a large single leaf at the end of line 10, and a sprig between stanzas 6 and 7 (line 13-14). A few other bits of vegetation, independent of the central vine, are notable: a serpentine or flame-like tendril in the top right corner and an elaborate extension of the initial "T" in "The End" (after line 26).

texthead.l: Urizen. C:IX.In Copy G, the Roman numeral "I" preceding "Urizen" has been erased.

lg.l: They lived a period of years
Then left a noisom body
To the jaws of devouring darkness
5. And their children wept, & built
Tombs in the desolate places.
And form'd laws of prudence, and
call'd them
The eternal laws of God
6, And the thirty cities remaind
Surrounded by salt floods, now call'd
Africa; its name was then Egypt.
7. The remaining sons of Urizen
Beheld their brethren shrink together
Beneath the Net of Urizen;
Perswasion was in vain;
For the ears of the inhabitants,
Were wither'd, & deafen'd, & cold;
And their eyes could not discern,
Their brethren of other cities,
8. So Fuzon call'd all together
The remaining children of Urizen:
And they left the pendulous earth:
They called it Egypt. & left it.
9. And the salt ocean rolled englob'd
The End of the
book of Urizen.In Copy G, the word "first" preceding "book" has been erased and covered by a tendril design.
